titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Beatrice Roman family photographs V1991.008
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Patricia Glowinski
titlestmt.sponsor: This collection was processed and described as part of the project, "Uncovering the Secrets of Brooklyn's 19th Century Past: Creation to Consolidation," funded by the Council on Library and Information Resources, with additional support from The Gladys Krieble Delmas Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2011-11-28T16:14-0500

physdesc.extent: three items housed in one manuscript box.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Beatrice Roman family photographs, dating from circa 1860 to 1920, consist of two black-and-white photographs and one photograph album containing both cartes-de-visite and cabinet photographs. The collection documents several families from which Beatrice Roman descended including the Koch family and the Peter family, both of which settled in the Brooklyn neighborhood of Bay Ridge. The collection consists of studio portraits with the exception of one group photograph showing boys dressed in military-style uniforms, surrounding a man who is possibly their teacher. The only sitter in the portraits that is identified is Herbert Self, a grocer from Bay Ridge.

bioghist.head: Biographical note
bioghist.p: Beatrice Roman (full name Beatrice Koch Wehmann Roman) descended from German immigrants who settled in the Bay Ridge neighborhood of Brooklyn. Her maternal great-grandfather was Philip Koch (1822-1893), a carousel maker who emigrated from Germany circa 1848. Philip's son William Koch (also known as Billy Cook or Billy Koch), owned "Billy Cook's Saloon" in Bay Ridge which purportedly had a bowling alley in the basement. William Koch later became involved in the real estate business and was also an amateur photographer. Beatrice Roman's paternal great-grandfather, Henry Peter (d. 1883), also left Germany circa 1848, and was a builder who constructed large homes along Shore Road in Brooklyn. Beatrice Roman married Stephen W. Roman.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright for anonymously created items will remain in effect for 120 years following the date of creation. Copyright for unpublished works with a known creator are protected until 70 years following the death of the creator. For information on securing rights to publish or reproduce, please see the Brooklyn Historical Society Reproduction Rights Policy.

otherfindaid.head: Other Finding Aids
otherfindaid.p: Item level description and digital versions of images from the collection are available for searching via the image database in the library. Please consult library staff for more information.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date (if known); Beatrice Roman family photographs, V1991.008, Box number, Object ID number; Brooklyn Historical Society.

processinfo.head: Processing Information note
processinfo.p: Fully processed to the item level.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials note
separatedmaterial.p: See the accession file for a list of the other items that were donated by Beatrice Roman at the same time as the photographs. Framed portraits of family members, an atlas of Brooklyn, and several cameras were part of the original donation.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Brooklyn Historical Society hold a related collection, the William Koch glass plate negatives (V1985.004). Please consult library staff for more information.
